lessons.name: Red-Crowned Parrot
lessons.content: In 2011, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced that the red-crowned parrot warranted federal protection. They too acknowledged that the birds' homes have been lost, and that they've been poached for the pet trade. They want the birds to be protected by being on America's official list of endangered species.

lessons.name: Eclipse of 2017
lessons.content: During the eclipse of 2017, the Moon's shadow raced over the Earth's surface at more than 2,000 miles per hour. A roughly 65-mile-wide zone, called the path of totality, offered the best viewing. Stars and planets came out, and the Sun's corona glowed in a perfect circle around the dark side of the Moon.

lessons.name: Thomas Jefferson
lessons.content: Thomas Jefferson, the third of ten children, was born on April 13, 1743 in Shadwell, Virginia into a planter family. His parents were Peter and Jane Jefferson. He had six sisters and three brothers. At 9 years old Jefferson began studying Latin, Greek, and French; he also learned to ride horses, and began to study nature.

lessons.name: Food Allergies
lessons.content: Food allergies are fairly common amongst adults and even more so among children. Around 2% of adults and 8% of children suffer from some type of food allergy where the immune system makes a mistake and thinks a certain food protein is dangerous and attacks it. Common food allergies are to seafood and peanuts.

lessons.name: Stewardess
lessons.content: "Stewardesses" is the longest word that is typed with only the left hand. A stewardess is a woman who is employed to provide meals for and otherwise look after passengers on a ship or aircraft. These days, we typically use the term flight attendant, which can refer to a man or woman that performs this job. What other words are typed with only one hand?

lessons.name: Indiana
lessons.content: Indiana is a state in the United States. Its capital and largest city is Indianapolis. Other famous cities and towns include Bloomington, Gary, Ft. Wayne, South Bend, Evansville, Muncie, and Marion. People who live in Indiana or are from there are called Hoosiers. Indiana's state bird is a Cardinal, Indiana's state flower is a Peony, Indiana's state tree is a Tulip Tree.

lessons.name: Smart Phones
lessons.content: Nowadays, phones are clever enough to grasp your physical surroundings. They can detect the size of a room and the presence of other people. Kids studying the Mesozoic Era would be able to place a virtual Tyrannosaurus in their home or classroom. The technology would even know when to display information about a scene depicted in a painting as you stroll through a museum.

lessons.name: Stars vs. Sand
lessons.content: Which do you think there are more of: stars in the universe, or grains of sand on the beach? There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on the beach. Try to picture that! However, there are more atoms in a single grain of sand than either stars in the universe or grains of sand on the beach. Pretty neat, right?

lessons.name: Elbert Hubbard
lessons.content: "A friend is someone who knows all about you and still loves you." Elbert Hubbard was an American writer, publisher, artist, and philosopher in the late 19th century and early 20th century. He is well known for founding an Arts & Crafts community in East Aurora, New York called Roycroft.

lessons.name: Emerson
lessons.content: "To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment." - Ralph Waldo Emerson. Emerson was an American essayist, lecturer, and poet in the mid-19th century. He is well known as a champion of individualism, and for leading the transcendentalism movement.

lessons.name: Citing a Source
lessons.content: If you use someone else's idea on your project, make sure to give them credit by mentioning their name. If you took the idea from a website, or a book, put the website's address or the book's name. This is called citing a source. Citing a source is how you can include someone else's text in your project without getting into trouble.

lessons.name: Secretary of State
lessons.content: Jefferson was selected by George Washington as the first Secretary of State. Jefferson thought that the federal government should be small. He had the opposite view of Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton about the federal government. Jefferson ran for president against John Adams. He got the second highest number of votes and as was the law at the time, became vice-president.

lessons.name: Pride & Prejudice
lessons.content: Pride and Prejudice is a piece of classical literature by Jane Austen. The story is so popular that it has been made into a movie not once, but twice. The book depicts a high born gentleman Mr. Darcy who falls in love with a young woman Elizabeth. Elizabeth comes from a family far beneath him socially. The couple must overcome many obstacles to finally realize their desire to marry.

lessons.name: Virtual Reality
lessons.content: Virtual reality games are different from ordinary games. Players don't look at a phone or TV screen when playing. Instead, they put the virtual reality device on their heads and over their eyes. These devices are called headsets. They close you off from the real world and make you feel like you are inside the game.

lessons.name: Human Senses
lessons.content: Humans have more than five senses. Although definitions vary, the actual number ranges from 9 to more than 20. In addition to sight, smell, taste, touch, and hearing, which were the senses identified by Aristotle, humans can sense balance and acceleration, pain, body and limb position, and relative temperature.

lessons.name: Hairdresser
lessons.content: Hairdressers help people cut, color, and style their hair. Qualified staff are usually called "stylists". Most hairdressing businesses serve both male and female customers. Male hairdressers who cut men's hair using a buzzer and a pair of scissors are often called barbers. The prestige of the job has been steadily growing over the past years.

lessons.name: Electoral College
lessons.content: The Electoral College consists of 538 electors. A majority of 270 electoral votes is required to elect the President. Your state's entitled allotment of electors equals the number of members in its Congressional delegation: one for each member in the House of Representatives plus two for your Senators. The president of the USA gets elected every four years.
